bibl.title: Letter from John M. Gibson to Philip Showalter Hench, September 10, 1951

div1.p: Gibson informs Hench that he is planning a biography of Sternberg. He learned about Hench's interest in Reed from a recent newspaper article, and would like access any Reed-Sternberg material from Hench's collection. Gibson also mentions having published a biography on Gorgas.

div1.head: Letter from John M. Gibson to Philip Showalter Hench, September 10, 1951
div1.opener:
State of Alabama
Department of Public Health
Montgomery 4, Alabama
September 10, 1951
D. G. GILL, M. D.
STATE HEALTH OFFICER
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
For some time I have been collecting material for my forthcoming
biography of General George Miller Sternberg. General Sternberg, as I am sure
you do not need to be told, was Surgeon General of the Army from 1893 to 1902.

For that reason, I read with great interest indeed the Associated Press story
on Mrs. Blossom Reed, of Blue Ridge Summit, Pa., daughter of Major Walter Reed,
who was closely associated with General Sternberg in a number of bacteriological
experiments, including and particularly the Havana studies that led to the
adoption of the mosquito theory of yellow fever transmission. I also found most
interesting the final paragraph of the A. P. story, as published in the Montgomery
paper, stating that letters and other Reed material were included in a yellow
fever collection now in your charge.

I am sure you readily realize how valuable such material would be to my
Sternberg biography. I presume that you have a number of letters from Reed to Stern-
berg and from Sternberg to Reed, and I am anxious to see these, if I possibly can.
Through the kindness of members of General Sternberg's family and others, I have
obtained a great deal of material for the book, but I particularly wish to get a
number of unpublished letters and other unpublished material. And of course material
dealing with the yellow fever investigations would be a prize indeed.

How can I obtain access to any Reed-Sternberg material in your collection?
Could I have it copied without too great expense, or photostated? Or could I have
the use of the originals on my solemn promise to see that they are taken care of
and promptly returned after being studied and copied? To protect you on that
score, I shall be glad to make a deposit of a reasonable amount, to be returned
upon the return of the material.

You may have seen my biography of General William C. Gorgas, published last
fall. It is now in a second printing after a friendly and indeed pleasant critical
and public reception. You probably have seen some of the reviews. I am enclosing
a leaflet describing the book.

I am also sending along a stamped and addressed envelope for your convenience in
replying.

I assure you of my grateful appreciation of your help in making this material
available to me.
